oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Alvin C. York story -- sunbonnet and homemade broom

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Country life; Domestic life; Housework; Houses; Women; Clothing & dress; Bonnets; Older people; Handicraft; Brooms & brushes

Ganier, Albert Franklin, 1883-1973; York, Alvin Cullum, 1887-1964; Sergeant York (Motion picture); Fentress County (Tenn.) -- Social life and custom; Country life -- Tennessee; Cumberland Mountains -- Economic conditions
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A woman is standing on a porch near a wash tub with a wash board inside. The tub is raised by laying a wooden chair on its side. Two large lard cans just visible beside the chair may hold cleaning products. The woman is dressed in a sunbonnet, dark blouse, and a wet, tattered apron that hangs to just above her ankles. Her stockings are wrinkled and her shoes appear wet. In her right hand she holds a tall homemade broom that appears to be very roughly made.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Albert F. Ganier
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The straw for brooms comes from broom straw or broomcorn, a relative of sorghum cane. The seeds are combed from the seed head, leaving the straw or bristles which are bunched around a handle, then tied or woven to it.
